content:
Hare and Tortoise 
 (Again!) 
 
 Venkatramana Gowda and 
 Divaspathy Hegde 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Do you remember the Great Race 
 betwen the hare and the tortoise? 
 
 
 For a long time, no one in the entire 
 animal kingdom could talk about 
 
 anything but the Great Race and its two 
 contestants. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 We al know that the rabit was defeated because he was lazy and 
 
 overconfident. 
 
 We know that the tortoise won the race because he was slow and steady.
 
 The forest animals knew this to, and continued to respect both creatures
 equaly. 
 
 
 Even the two competitors remained friends. The tortoise did not asume
 airs because he had won, and the hare, realising he had ben defeated fair
 
 and square, bore the tortoise no grudge. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Many months pased. The king of the
 jungle where the hare and the tortoise
 lived had some important maters to
 
 discus with the king of the neighbouring
 jungle. 
 But the first king could not leave his
 
 jungle just then. He decided, instead, to
 send the hare and tortoise to the
 
 neighbouring king, as his 
 representatives. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 "At least one of you must go to the neighbouring kingdom," 
 
 ordered the king, when the hare and the tortoise had 
 presented themselves. 
 
 
 "I want you to discus certain important maters with the 
 king there, and come back to me with his thoughts on those 
 maters." 
 
 
 "Now go!" he said, as he dismised them. "And mind, you 
 
 only have a day to complete the task." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The road to the neighbouring kingdom
 
 was not smoth or easy. 
 
 It was rocky and ful of thorns.
 
 
 There were also two rivers to cros on
 
 the way. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 After some thought, both the hare and 
 the tortoise realised that neither of them 
 could complete the task alone. 
 
 
 They had to travel together. 
 
 
 The plan was for the hare to cary the 
 tortoise over the thorny parts of the 
 
 route, and for the tortoise to cary the 
 hare acros the two rivers. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The next day, they colected the various
 mesages from their king and were ready
 
 to go. 
 
 The hare made short work of the thorny
 
 parts of the route with his giant loping
 strides, while the tortoise held on for
 
 dear life. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When they came to a river, they switched 
 
 places, and the hare clambered onto the 
 tortoise's back. 
 
 
 The tortoise swam acros the river 
 gracefuly. 
 
 
 Once both rivers had ben crosed, it did 
 not take them long to arive at the 
 
 neighbouring kingdom. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 After long discusions with the 
 
 neighbouring king on al the maters
 raised by their own king, the hare and the
 tortoise were ready to leave. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The journey home was even smother 
 than the outward journey, since both the 
 
 hare and the tortoise now knew exactly 
 what to do. 
 
 
 The two old rivals had worked so wel 
 that they reached the king wel ahead of 
 
 the deadline he had set!
